Why French politics can't cope without an absolute majority
subhead: While most European countries have learned to manage their fragmented parliaments, France has failed to adapt. The 'fait majoritaire,' the political dominance of a president backed by a parliamentary majority, has so deeply shaped politics since 1962 that lawmakers have been unable to envision governments built on a base of negotiation and compromise.

Romania, Poland, scramble aircraft as drones strike Ukraine
subhead: Romania's defense ministry said Saturday that the country's airspace had been breached by a drone during a Russian attack on infrastructure in neighboring Ukraine.

headline: Israeli intelligence admits Iran's nuclear program has not been destroyed
subhead: Israeli officials have recently provided French authorities with their own assessment of the airstrikes that targeted Tehran's nuclear arsenal in June. This information is particularly valuable to France after American intelligence agencies have halted all cooperation with their European partners regarding the Iranian nuclear program.

headline: Hôtel California, a family passion
subhead: Its pink neon sign, reminiscent of an American motel, shines like an emblem in the sky over Le Lavandou, southeastern France. Managed by the same family  since it was built in 1956, Hôtel California – with its accessible, laid-back chic – is also a dream come true: a place where everyone can enjoy a vacation, feet in the water and no schedule to keep.

headline: Sex workers on content platforms open up to their parents
subhead: Since the Covid-19 pandemic, pornographic content platforms have been booming, attracting a young audience – mainly women – who turn to sex work for the money and independence it offers. Some choose to speak to their parents about it. Those conversations can either create distance or bring them closer together.

Nan Goldin, photographer: 'The camera gave me a voice, and a way in'
subhead: 'I wouldn't be here if...' Each week, Le Monde asks a public figure about a decisive moment in their life. The American photographer reflects on her sister's suicide, which changed her view of the world.

headline: Tasting clubs are discreetly shaping France's wine culture
subhead: Thousands of enthusiasts gather in associations or informal groups, whether at home or in bars, for themed tastings – some highly structured. The values of sharing and passing on knowledge drive these get-togethers.

headline: When everyday hatred turns to racist murder: 'I don't know why I lost it. I have no idea'
subhead: On May 31, Christophe Belgembe, a mechanic, fatally shot his neighbor Hichem Miraoui and tried to kill five other people in the southern French town of Puget-sur-Argens. Though he had made racist remarks for years, he struggled to explain his actions.
byline: Jérôme Lefilliâtre and  Lorraine de Foucher
